lead_paragraph: SPIEGEL--Siegmund. Architect and Holocaust survivor, born in Gera, Germany 1919, died July 14, 2016 while with his family, celebrating the 95th birthday of his beloved wife, Ruth. He fled Nazi Germany and lived his life honoring the deaths of his and Ruth's parents and all who died in the Holocaust. He volunteered to be drafted into the U.S. Army in 1941, serving in the G-2 section of the 1st Infantry Division, 'The Big Red One', through the invasions of North Africa, Sicily, and France. As an Architect, he received many awards for housing, planning, commercial, and institutional projects. He co-founded the Black- Jewish Coalition of Long Island and the Nassau County Holocaust Commission, and designed its Holocaust Memorial and Education Center. In the early 70's, Sig became very active in Jewish philanthropic work, founding the Architects, Engineers and Builders Division of United Jewish Appeal of Long Island. He served as President of the Long Island Board of the Anti-Defamation League, was active in B'nai B'rith, and organized Holocaust Victims Memorials. He lectured in schools about the Holocaust throughout his life. For his service in the Infantry and Military Intelligence, he attained the rank of Master Sergeant. And for his bravery he was awarded the Purple Heart, Bronze Star, the Croix de-Guerre-Avec Palme by the Belgian government, and the "Chevalier of the French Legion of Honor" by the French Government. Sig will be buried at Arlington National Cemetery with full military honors at a date to be announced. He is survived by his beloved family: wife of over 71 years, Ruth, daughters Sandra Bauman McGrath, Deborah Spiegel Rockwerk (husband Sandy), grandson Brandon Spiegel Bauman, nieces Susan Maier, Ada Golan Meir and nephew Amos Golan. Contributions in his memory can be made to The Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington D.C. and the Anti-Defamation League. 1/3
